Observation of suspicious web domains or.Action: Monitor external search results for keywords relevant to the organization. Cross-reference identified suspicious domains with internal Zeek dns.log and http.log for any resolution or connection attempts, even automated ones like web crawlers or security tools initiated from the network.

Internal users navigating to suspicious.Action: Analyze Zeek http.log for connections to domains identified as suspicious via external monitoring or threat intelligence. Use correlation analysis to identify users frequently accessing newly registered or low-reputation domains found through search results. Analyze HTTP request headers (e.g., Referer) for indications that the site was reached via a search engine.

Network traffic patterns exhibiting char.Action: Analyze Zeek http.log for connections originating from search engine referers that result in immediate multiple redirects (HTTP status codes 301, 302, 307, 308). Identify connections with unusual HTTP headers (e.g., crafted User-Agent strings, suspicious Accept-Language values, unexpected missing Referer) often used for traffic validation by malicious sites. Use frequency analysis on header values and redirect chains to identify statistical outliers.

Internal user visits originating from se.Action: Correlate Zeek http.log entries with Referer headers indicating search engines with Zeek dns.log entries to identify domains visited via search results. Filter these domains based on threat intelligence feeds for low reputation or new registration dates. Analyze requested URIs in http.log for suspicious file extensions (e.g., .exe, .zip, .iso, .dll, macro-enabled documents) from these domains. Use descriptive statistics (e.g., count of visits to flagged domains per user) to identify unusual user behavior.
